text: 12floz bottle ($10/four-pack, no apparent freshness date) poured into a tulip glass. Rusty-brown body with a 2-3 finger head that is very slow to settle. Smells really good, like subdued candied sweet potatoes. This isnt a spectacular ale, but it is very good. Its full in body, yet not heavy. Its definitely yeast and malt centric. Raisin, sweet potato, tobacco, and molasses play well together with an unknown (allspice?) yeasty flavor adding to the melting pot of flavors. A fine beer that finishes without any lingering qualities.

12oz bottle. Amber cloudy color with an off white head. Sweet yeast lemon aroma. Sweet lemon cherry light tartness flavour. Medium body. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Brilliant appearance, reddish, a bit dark, hazy, nice lasting tan head. Dark fruit in the nose along with a bit of yeastiness. Taste is initially very clean, then a bit of caramel and dark fruit, and the yeast, a bit of banana at the end. Mouthfeel is neutral, small fine carbonation, a bit sweet, but finishes quite dry. Masterfully done. Yeah a doppelbock they called a dark strong belgian,

Pours from bottle a murky copper-chestnut, with appearance saved by a dense café au lait head, about 1½ fingers, that sticks around with nice lacing and cap.
The nose is undramatic, primarily malt, toast and yeast, but clove note begins to come through. Thats more prominent on the palate, which also develops dried fruit, biscuit and a broader spiciness with cardamom and white pepper joining the clove. Theres a hint of nuts and earthiness leading to an attractive herbal finish.
A touch of creaminess complements the medium body. Overall, not quite Belgian, but very nice on a cool evening.

12 ounce bottle into signature tulip glass, no bottle dating. Pours fairly hazy/cloudy reddish copper/light brown color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense and fluffy light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of big raisin, plum, fig, cherry, apple, banana, bubblegum, peppercorn, clove, caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toasted biscuit, light nuttiness/chocolate, and herbal/yeast/toasted earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of fruity/spicy yeast and dark/bready/light roasted malt notes; with great strength. Taste of big raisin, plum, fig, cherry, apple, banana, bubblegum, peppercorn, clove, caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toasted biscuit, light nuttiness/chocolate, and herbal/yeast/toasted earthiness. Moderate yeast spiciness and light herbal bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark fruit, banana, bubblegum, peppercorn, clove, caramel, brown sugar, brown bread, toasted biscuit, light nuttiness/chocolate, and herbal/yeast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/spicy yeast and dark/bready/light roasted malt flavors; with a great malt/spiciness balance, and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light-moderate dryness from carbonation and yeast spiciness as well. Medium-high carbonation and medium-plus body; with a very smooth, creamy/bready/grainy, fairly crisp, and lightly sticky/chalky balanced mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is fairly well hidden, a mild warmth lingering after the finish. Overall this is a very nice Belgian dark ale/Doppelbock hybrid style. All around nice complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/spicy yeast and dark/bready/light roasted malt flavors; very smooth, crisp, and easy to drink for the ABV. Pretty much perfectly balanced between yeast and malt flavors; with impressive complexity from both yeast and malt as well. A very enjoyable offering.

Pours hazy brown with a thin, creamy head. Aromas of banana, clove and sweet malt. Flavors are clove, banana, spice, toffee and earthy hops. Substantial breadiness. Peppery mouthfeel. Im not sure why "doppelbock" is on the label. This is totally a Belgian, but its very nice.

Poured from 12 oz. bottle. 

Hazy, amber-brown with a thin khaki head and very good lacing. 

Aroma of toffee, plums, dried fruit and spice. 

Taste of caramel, spice, dried fruit, toast and mild, but persistent tart dark fruit. 

Medium body and medium carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle - $3.79 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours a hazy, medium-toned amber-brown body with an inch of thickish, long-lasting, light beige head.

Smell: Toasty baked bread with a coating of darkish caramel. Chopped dried fruits swirled with spirits. Slight, sharp clove and cardamom notes convey some spiciness.

Taste: Sweet and bready with a golden syrup, caramel quality. Quickly regains the phenolic spiciness from the aroma with a sustained flavor of cracked clove. Fruity tastes of bananas, red berries, plums and dates. Slightly herbal on the sweetish, warming finish with the clove lingering into the aftertaste.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Fluffy, lightly sticky mouthfeel with some plush carbonation.

Overall: Its sufficient.

12oz bottle. Medium beige head atop hazy dark amber body. Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, white pepper, some spicy, cherry. Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, some white pepper, light Belgian yeast spicy, cherry. Soft effervescent medium body, light stickiness.

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle stamped 6060952120905. Decent looking reddish-amber pour under a long lasting head. The aroma is slightly fruity with cracker malts but no booze. Medium body. The taste has a somewhat forward boozy-roasted malt character unlike other Belgian Strong Ales I have had. There is a clean character about it and a mild bitterness to end.

Bottle from Milk and Hops, Chelsea. Pours a dark amber / chestnut-brown color with a nice fizzy froth of tan head. Theres a good amount of lace on the glass as well. Belgian yeast, clove, banana, caramel, and some nutty notes. Fairly sweet, with some dark fruit and brown sugar coming through as well on the flavor. Over carbonated. A bit sticky. Pretty good, with the mouthfeel bring my least favorite component of an otherwise well made beer.

Draft taproom. Reddish pour. Aroma of gum, yeast. Flavor is gum, yeast, banana, toast. Meh. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Brewtopia. Clear amber with long-lasting tan head and lace. Toasted caramel bready earthy aroma with a touch of banana. Toasted caramel woody earthy grainy sweetness with spicy woody medium-light bitter finish. Soft body seems to lack the traditional minerally feel of the German double bocks. Very good.

Shared 12 oz. bottle poured to a snifter, showing a brownish amber color, with fairly persistent, tan head foam, and wavy spots & strands of lacing. The nose was smooth maltiness, toast & caramel, with dried fruit, spice, and subtle tartness & tanginess throughout. Medium bodied, with decent carbonation, the taste was similar notes, a little warmth, and mild creaminess to the mouthfeel. A tasteful collaboration no matter how you pigeon-hole the style.

Sample at the Aficionados beer tasting on 12/08/2016. Hazy reddish-mahogany color with a medium off-white head that diminishes gradually to a film. Partial rings of lacing. The aroma consists of yeast, dark fruit and caramel malt. Medium body with flavors of earthy yeast, citrus, malt and caramel. The finish is Belgian yeast and malt. Pretty good overall.

12oz bottle. Deep unfiltered brown-burgundy body. Steady off-white head. Bready, fruity, and interesting melding of doppelbock and dubbel. Quality through and through, I really enjoyed this beer. Great mouthfeel. Lots of depth..brown sugar, caramel, red fruits, purple fruits, amber malt. Really well done beer.

Bottle from andersons. Nose is bread, caramel, roasty malt. Not as thick mouth feel as Id like from a dopplebock but well balanced. Medium bitterness, slick feel, soft carbonation. Notes of clove, banana, floral spice.  not quite a true dopplebock but has some european ale influences.  Pretty good and would do again.

Clear, copper color. Big, yellowish head. Aroma of caramel, figs, dark fruits and ...clove. Moderate sweetness in taste with distinctive hoppy notes at the end. Malty, caramel and ...yeasty. Hard to call this beer a doppelbock . Anyway , it s very tasty!

Pour is a dark brown with a huge tan head. Aroma is a nice clove and dark fruit malt. Flavor is a definate dark fruit malt with a big cherry with some spice and figs. Finish leaves some Belgian yeast esters on the tongue. This beer is not is not defined by one style. Its part doppel, weizenbock and dubbel all at the same time. Very flavorful and each sip brings out a different aspect of each style.

Bottle. Deep copper brown pour, tremendous off-white head with exceptional retention and lacing. Nose is caramel, dried fruit, clove, banana, toast. Mouth is medium bodied, creamy, mildly sweet, figs, dates, caramel, dried grass, raisins, brown sugar. Quite good. I certainly wouldnt call this a doppel by any means, but I would absolutely call it very tasty.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2016 Bottle. Brown with two+ finger head. I?m not a fan of dopplebocks, but I?ll try just about anything. Like others have noted, this has more in common with a really good weizenbock. Dark fruit, banana, clove. Excellent, whatever it is.

Clear light brown with a small cap of beige foam. Aromas of candi sugar, plums, caramel along with yeasty banana and bubblegum. While nice, does not smell like a dopplebock. The same is true of the flavor. Similar to the nose with a slightly earthy bitter hop, this strays further from the style. A bit disappointing, but interesting.

Bottle. Head is initially large, creamy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is hazy medium brownish-amber. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, cookie), lightly hoppy (herbs, flowers), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of banana/gum, raisin, clove, orange peel. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium to full body, velvety/creamy texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Most closely resembles a Weizenbock, which was my first thought when I took a whiff right after pouring. German Weissbier yeast and Belgian yeast strains often produce similar aromas (banana/gum, clove), and that is true here. Blinded, I would definitely guess that style (and this is an ale yeast, yet another good reason to call this a Weizenbock as opposed to Doppelbock). Nice yeasty tartness that you usually get from that style too. Lovely tightly-packed tiny bubbles that last to the end, along with the hazy body make for a perfect appearance too. Another winner from Ommegang. Falls just a bit short of 4+ wonderment, but its a very solid beer in all respects.

Bottle purchased at Spruce Creek Provisions, Kittery. The nose is Ommegang house yeast, brown bread, raisins and light spice like tones. The taste is bitter-sweet, caramel and brown sugar upfront. The backbone is house yeast. The finish is dark fruits with toffee, dry texture, slight warming alcohol finish. 
Medium plus body and fine carbonation. Smooth and well-rounded. The flavor is more a Abbey Dubbel rather then a German Doppelbock but it is good.
Reddish brown. Nose of Belgian yeast and candy with sweet toasted malt. Flavor of yeast spice and sugary toast.

Bottle from a Lazy Dog
Slightly hazy deep chestnut in color with a tightly bubbled off white head that persists. The label said dopplebock but it surprised me with clove and peppery yeastiness on the nose. Rich burnt caramel and candy malt flavor with plenty of yeasty spiciness to counter. Bubbly mouthfeel medium body spirited carbonation. Pretty tasty beer, kind of a mild quad with a bit less fruit.

Dark brown, almost dark ruby, opaque with a moderate tan head. Moderate to full body. Thick. Taste is dark fruit (raisin and plum), some malty sweetness, and a bit of caramel. Nose is sweet caramel and malty

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2016 Four-pack of slender bottles. Nose very sweet and forthright with its fruitiness -- cherry and very bright orange peel, close to a Belgian ester profile. Pour deep caramel out of the neck but accumulates to glowing ruby in the glass, supports a large and fluffy beige head. Body medium but light, still heavily malty with lots of melanoidin development and pumpernickel crust, though everything remains subject to that slightly fumy fruitiness. More plum, some roast and earthy-treacle character near to scorch, dash of air but no more. Gets decent lace and might even see some legs. A very nice subdued nuttiness (walnut? pecan?) than lingers in the long, light-medium bitter aftertaste. Medium-strong clove and phenolics in general, strong spice blend. Quite nice, classy, complex, but hard to shake the idea its a Rochefort 8 clone rather than a Doppelbock. [2016.11.28: 3.8]
Too good to be below a four.  Again, not a DB, but so vibrant and alive, shockingly fresh.  [2016.11.30: 4.2]
Hazy dark amber pour from a 12oz bottle. Nice caramel and malty nose. Nice taste, a bit phenolic and hot in the finish.

355ml bottle. So what is presented here seems to be a strong dark ale with ommegang yeast? Because that screams doppelbock... This is a bit like a winter warmer, cinnamon and clove notes, baked bread, caramel. A doppelbock this is not...

Bottle. It poured a cloudy golden color with a white head. The aroma was of malts, fruits and some caramel. The taste was similar to the aroma with more malts, caramel, fruits, bread, bananas and spice. Decent.
Sample at Strong Ale Fest 2016. Comes a hazy reddish brown with a nice tan head. Aroma of malt, fruit, and caramel. Taste is malt, caramel, dark fruit, bread, and spice. Nice one.

Hazy brown liquid with a very tall, and expanding, somewhat rocky, khaki colored head. Aromas of dark toasted malt and grains. A touch of molasses and sorghum. Some mild fruit, and somewhat floral/herbal hops. A bit of yeast, with some phenols. A mix of a dubbel and a weizenbock. Full feel, but enough zip to help it from being overbearing. Sweet start with some complex sugars. Herbal notes work their way in. Quite complex. Could not have more than one or two of these at a setting, but Id enjoy them. Fairly dry finish with a touch of wood and tobacco.

The beer pours chestnut brown with a large dense tan head. The aroma has raisins, toffee, toasty malt, Belgian yeast and bread - kinda between a doppelbock and dubbel which is what they were going for. It has a medium rich body with a lot of soft carbonation. The taste has the aroma notes with some creaminess, gentle spice and caramel. This is much better than I thought it was going to be. Very nicely done.
Aroma is dark fruit/plums, malts and Belgian yeast. The flavor is plums, Belgian yeast, malts, mild sweetness in the middle and an acidic finish.

Bottle - hazy Amber - doppelbock with a Belgian yeast - interesting experiment - winds up tasting very much like a dubbel - rich malt nose of caramel and dark fruit, along with clove and white pepper - flavor is similar - rich maltiness, but not overly sweet - some plum and caramel - clove, banana, cherry, raisin - light acidity cuts the maltiness - interesting.
Beer and Smoke, Brooklyn bottle: pours mahogony with a loose head. Aroma is dark fruit and malts. Taste is lightly sweet. Hefty malts. Low hops. Pretty easy to drink. Not bad.

Pours deep mahogany into a stem glass. Off-white head with excellent retention recedes leaving sheet lacing. Banana, clove and pit fruit aromas. Hot caramel and banana upfront turning to clove in the lasting finish.

12 oz bottle pours a dark Amber color with a nice white head. Aromas of caramel, malt, biscuit. Medium bodied, nice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12 ounce bottle. Pours a copper caramel looking color with nice rich caramel and yeasty notes. Yeast really shines. Tasty.
